segment.source: User Account Control Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation (Windows 10)
segment.target: User Account Control Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the User Account Control Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the User Account Control Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation security policy setting.

segment.source: User Account Control: Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation
segment.target: User Account Control: Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the User Account Control: Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management and security considerations for the User Account Control: Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation security policy setting.

segment.source: This policy setting determines whether the elevation request prompts on the interactive user desktop or on the secure desktop.
segment.target: This policy setting determines whether the elevation request prompts on the interactive user desktop or on the secure desktop.

segment.source: The secure desktop presents the logon UI and restricts functionality and access to the system until the logon requirements are satisfied.
segment.target: The secure desktop presents the logon UI and restricts functionality and access to the system until the logon requirements are satisfied.

segment.source: The secure desktop’s primary difference from the user desktop is that only trusted processes running as SYSTEM are allowed to run here (that is, nothing is running at the user’s privilege level).
segment.target: The secure desktop’s primary difference from the user desktop is that only trusted processes running as SYSTEM are allowed to run here (that is, nothing is running at the user’s privilege level).

segment.source: The path to get to the secure desktop from the user desktop must also be trusted through the entire chain.
segment.target: The path to get to the secure desktop from the user desktop must also be trusted through the entire chain.

segment.source: All elevation requests by default go to the secure desktop.
segment.target: All elevation requests by default go to the secure desktop.

segment.source: All elevation requests go to the interactive user desktop.
segment.target: All elevation requests go to the interactive user desktop.

segment.source: Enable the User Account Control: Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation setting.
segment.target: Enable the User Account Control: Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation setting.

segment.source: The secure desktop helps protect against input and output spoofing by presenting the credentials dialog box in a protected section of memory that is accessible only by trusted system processes.
segment.target: The secure desktop helps protect against input and output spoofing by presenting the credentials dialog box in a protected section of memory that is accessible only by trusted system processes.

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options

segment.source: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.
segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default values for this policy.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes features and tools that are available to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.
segment.target: Changes to this policy become effective without a device restart when they are saved locally or distributed through Group Policy.

segment.source: All auditing capabilities are integrated in Group Policy.
segment.target: All auditing capabilities are integrated in Group Policy.

segment.source: You can configure, deploy, and manage these settings in the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC) or Local Security Policy snap-in for a domain, site, or organizational unit (OU).
segment.target: You can configure, deploy, and manage these settings in the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC) or Local Security Policy snap-in for a domain, site, or organizational unit (OU).

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: Elevation prompt dialog boxes can be spoofed, causing users to disclose their passwords to malicious software.
segment.target: Elevation prompt dialog boxes can be spoofed, causing users to disclose their passwords to malicious software.

segment.source: Mouse cursors can be spoofed by hiding the real cursor and replacing it with an offset so the cursor is actually pointing to the Allow button.
segment.target: Mouse cursors can be spoofed by hiding the real cursor and replacing it with an offset so the cursor is actually pointing to the Allow button.

segment.source: Enable the User Account Control: Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation setting.
segment.target: Enable the User Account Control: Switch to the secure desktop when prompting for elevation setting.

segment.source: The secure desktop helps protect against input and output spoofing by presenting the credentials dialog box in a protected section of memory that is accessible only by trusted system processes.
segment.target: The secure desktop helps protect against input and output spoofing by presenting the credentials dialog box in a protected section of memory that is accessible only by trusted system processes.
